facts.text: Respondent first arrested on 18th December 1948 under Bombay Public Security Measures Act, 1948 (Bombay Act IV of 1947).
Respondent arrested again on 21st April 1950 under Preventive Detention Act, 1950.
On 29th April 1950, grounds for detention supplied: 'That you are engaged and are likely to be engaged in promoting acts of sabotage on railway and railway property in Greater Bombay.'
Respondent filed habeas corpus petition on 31st July 1950, contending grounds vague, no particulars, mala fide, aimed at trade unionists.
On 9th August 1950, Bombay High Court directed issue of notice to Commissioner of Police.
On 26th August 1950, Commissioner of Police sent communication under section 7: activities in Greater Bombay between January 1950 and date of detention, likely to continue.

On 30th August 1950, Commissioner filed affidavit: objectionable activities Jan 1950 to detention; move for railway strike March 1950; advocating sabotage; reliable materials; strike idea continued; denial respondent out of Bombay post Nov 1949.
Bombay High Court granted petition on 1st September 1950, holding initial grounds vague and supplementary not permissible.
In January 1950, move for total railway strike in March 1950; respondent taking prominent part; advocating sabotage to make strike successful.

legal_issues.text: Whether the initial grounds supplied on 29th April 1950 were vague and insufficient to enable representation under Article 22(5).
Whether detaining authority can furnish supplementary particulars or facts after initial grounds, without violating Article 22(5).
Whether court can examine sufficiency of grounds for enabling representation, distinct from sufficiency for subjective satisfaction under section 3.

petitioner_arguments.text: Objection to High Court's approach that supplementary grounds cannot be furnished after initial grounds; grounds must enable representation but can be supplemented with facts, not new grounds.
Satisfaction under s.3 is subjective; grounds need rational connection to objects; not for court to substitute objective test.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act s.3; Gopalan's case

petitioner_arguments.text: Further particulars supplied were facts supporting original ground, not new grounds; public interest allows withholding details.

respondent_arguments.text: Initial ground vague, no particulars of when, where, what sabotage; not enabling proper representation; mala fide to lock up trade unionists.
Detaining authority cannot amplify/improve grounds later; violation at time of furnishing initial grounds (29 Apr 1950) cannot be cured.
After release Nov 1949, stayed in Ratlam and Delhi till 20 Apr 1950; not in Bombay during alleged period.

court_reasoning.text: Article 22(5) gives two rights: (1) grounds as soon as may be; (2) earliest opportunity for representation. Grounds are conclusions from facts; must supply all such conclusions existing at order time, but facts can be supplemented later if not new grounds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Supplementary communication of facts supporting original ground permissible if not creating new ground and within time for representation.

court_reasoning.text: Satisfaction under s.3 subjective; court examines only rational connection/mala fides, not sufficiency per se. Vagueness for satisfaction not justiciable, but vagueness preventing representation is.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two distinct tests: for satisfaction (subjective, rational nexus); for representation (sufficient info to enable it).

court_reasoning.text: Initial ground had rational connection; later particulars were facts (e.g., Jan-Mar 1950 activities) supporting it, not new; supplied timely.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in rejecting later communication solely because after initial grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Patanjali Sastri J. (separate): Court cannot examine sufficiency of grounds for representation; only subjective satisfaction matters; Art 22(6) gives discretion on disclosure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No judicial review of grounds' sufficiency for representation; executive discretion final.

court_reasoning.text: Das J. (separate): Vague grounds valid if subjective satisfaction genuine; communication must match grounds used; no obligation for particulars beyond that.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sufficiency for representation not justiciable; relation between grounds and representation exists but does not import objective test.

holdings.text: Detaining authority may furnish further facts/particulars after initial grounds if they elaborate original ground without adding new conclusions, provided timely for representation.
Grounds valid if rationally connected to s.3 objects; court cannot review subjective sufficiency for detention order.
In this case, initial grounds sufficient; later particulars valid elaboration; no violation of Art 22(5).

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 3 constitutional; subjective satisfaction; Art 21/22 apply with limits.
Preventive detention based on suspicion; court not appropriate tribunal.
Privilege against disclosure; subjective 'reasonable cause' not justiciable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Machindar Shivaji Mahar v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Subjective satisfaction; court examines relevance only.
Prima facie vagueness led to release; no arguments heard.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedural safeguards for preventive detention; grounds and representation rights.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950 (Act IV of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order; communication of grounds and particulars.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Public Security Measures Act, 1948 (Bombay Act IV of 1947)
Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to prior High Court cases on vagueness.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Bombay High Court order releasing the respondent, held detention valid as initial grounds complied with Art 22(5) and later particulars were permissible elaboration.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; habeas corpus petition dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "The grounds being the heads, from which the Government was satisfied that it was necessary to pass the order of detention, there can be no addition to those grounds."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the later communication contains facts leading to a conclusion which is outside the ground first supplied, the same cannot be looked into as supporting the order of detention."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is not for the court to sit in the place of the Central Government or the State Government and try to determine if it would have come to the same conclusion."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits judicial review to rational nexus/mala fides.

key_quotes.text: "The combined effect of clauses (5) and (6) is... to require the detaining authority to communicate... only such particulars as that authority... considers sufficient."
key_quotes.speaker: Patanjali Sastri J.
key_quotes.significance: No judicial review of sufficiency for representation.
